response.answer_text: Socrates is the individual responsible for starting the Aristotelian—Platonic debate that has persisted into the modern age. The following explanation is very simplified and deserves a deeper investigation if you are truly interested in the matter; that said, here is a primitive survey: Socrates reasoned that “being” either descends from an exalted, heavenly like place, or it comes from material experience. Plato advanced the former position and Aristotle advanced the latter position. Both schools of thought have informed modern views on math and physics, yet Socrates himself seems to have remained agnostic toward either. In this way, one might argue that Socrates was a pure philosopher in the sense that he could infer that there seemed to exist this dichotomy but was not necessarily given to one view or the other.

He was Plato’s teacher. Everything Plato knew or felt about philosophy, he learned it from Socrates. Socrates’ execution also deeply affected Plato. His political and moral philosophy is strongly influenced by his hatred of the system that got Socrates killed.

In short: socrates opposition against the sophiests that "definition" of things are true knowledge than perception of things lead plato to think about "concepts" and "ideas" and that's where he founded his system of idealism.
